Description: Hardwired tablet in every housing unit to display notifications, reminders, etc.
Easy compost chute, rainwater recycling, community garden, etc. instead of large, ambitious efforts towards sustainability,
Horseshoe shaped apartment complex that allows each unit to receive ample amounts of sunlight.
Directs rainwater runoff into central garden and waters greenery.
A cafe that uses produce from the community garden to provide cheap, and healthy food.
Appliances that can be detached from walls and moved around to convert ex. a living room into a kitchen.
No checks, no paper notifications, digital menu at community cafe, etc.
Walls that can be shaped, bent and pulled. (To change the layout of a home quickly.)
Makes it easier for people to recycle.
Takes furniture that residents don't want and refashions them into communal furniture.
Garden that provides produce to the cafe, or subsidized produce that residents can buy.
Automatically turns off lights and shuts off power to appliances when not in use
Windows change tint to allow more or less sunlight, reducing heating and cooling costs
Exercise bikes and treadmills produce electricity for community
Water is reused for the same purpose, i.e. toilet water is treated and reused for toilet water, same with laundry
Produce white noise/noise canceling that allows everyone to sleep in peace
Energy generating floor tiles installed in the floor supplement energy needs
Lets you compare energy use with other residents, see which outlets are using the most electricity
Community provided wifi free to use for residents
Spaces rented out to community residents that solves storage problems for those with many belongings
Free laundry services eliminates frustration of finding quarters for coin laundry
Storing spaces that can hold clothes then suck air to save space by keeping it as compact as possible.
In winter, windows get heated by sun during day, then release the heat at night to save energy.
Water taps and shower sinks can have small water turbines which when connected to generators can produce a fraction of needed power.
Walls can be made porous to allow for air renewal when it is too cold to ope windows.
Doors and windows can be mechanically connected to a generator that will generate energy every time they are opened or closed.
Doors can be designed to open downwards and act as ramps for disabled wheelchairs.
Bed can be installed beneath the floor with a sliding opening that can carry other furniture when closed.
The ground can have railway to facilitate motion of furniture especially that the place would be compact.
Desks can be set on top of each other to save horizontal space.
Walls can have hanging spots to hang whichever small piece of furniture that is not in current use.
Refrigerator that changes its temperature based on how many and what type of items in it to save energy.
Faucet that controls amount of water flowing through based on what type of usage.
Furniture that has multi functions.
For non-structural framework, use recycled materials.
Light system that travels on rail and adjusts itself for optimal lighting in the room to minimize amount of lighting needed in the room.
Sound assistant that helps people with visual disability with their way around the house.
Movable hand rail that assist elders with their way around the house while generating power through its movement.
Furnitures that have wheels on the bottom for wheelchair users to move them with ease.
On-site burner that burns trash and generate power for the heat.
Vacuum installed at the bottom of each wall that sucks up the dust daily.
